Developing low–cost and efficient materials for nitrobenzene reduction reaction (NBRR) is attractive and challengeable. Great research efforts have been made in metal–based materials, while the metal–free catalysts for nitrobenzene (Ph–NO2) conversion have been rarely explored. Herein, by means of density functional theory (DFT) calculations, the potential of B–doped C2N as metal–free photocatalyst for NBRR was systematically investigated. The results reveal that the sp2–hybridized B doped C2N at N site (BN–C2N) exhibits high catalytic activity for nitrobenzene conversion to aniline (Ph–NH2) with a low limiting potential of –0.30 V. Besides, BN–C2N can improve the photoconversion efficiency by broadening the light absorption of C2N. Therefore, BN–C2N is a promising metal–free photocatalyst for NBRR, which may open a new avenue for Ph–NO2 conversion under ambient conditions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal–free photocatalysts B–doped C2N Nitrobenzene reduction reaction Density functional theory 1 Introduction Aniline (Ph–NH2) is important reaction intermediate in organic chemical production as it is a critical chemical raw material for manufacture of dyes, medicaments, rubber and insecticides [1–11]. Currently, nitrobenzene (Ph–NO2) reduction to Ph–NH2 widely uses noble metal catalysts, such as Pd, Rh, Ru, Pt and Ag [12–19]. Although these noble metals are highly efficient, they still suffer from exorbitant price cost and poor selectivity [20]. In order to find a more economical and gentle solution, a variety of photocatalysts, such as Au/ZrO2, Au/TiO2, CdS/g–C3N4 and Ag/g–C3N4 [21–25] have been used to catalyze the Ph–NO2 reduction reaction (NBRR). During the hydrogenation reaction process, over–hydrogenation of the intermediates on the photocatalysts leads to the decrease in selectivity to the desired products [26–28]. Therefore, the exploration of cost effective and selective photocatalysts for Ph–NH2 synthesis is still a huge challenge [29–31]. Metal–free materials are promising alternatives for different reduction reactions due to their high efficiency, excellent stability, and low cost [32–40], among which heteroatom doping is useful to improve the catalytic performance of metal–free materials. For example, heteroatom–doped carbon materials with N, B or their co–doping have played a key role in oxygen reduction reaction [41–44]. Heteroatom–doped carbon materials can also be used to improve the catalytic performance of CO2 reduction reaction because the charge neutrality of the carbon materials can be greatly tailored by introducing heteroatoms [45–49]. It has been reported that B–doped g–C3N4 is a promising metal–free photocatalyst for N2 reduction with a low limiting potential (–0.20 V) [50], as the electron deficient B dopants can accept lone–pair electrons from N2 molecule, activating the inert N–N bond and further promoting its cleavage. However, we note that metal–free catalysts for Ph–NO2 conversion have been rarely explored. Thus, we are inspired to develop high–efficiency metal–free photocatalysts for NBRR. In 2015, C2N with evenly distributed holes was successfully synthesized by a wet chemical method [51]. The natural holey structure of C2N makes it an excellent support to host one or two atoms to catalyze the CO and N2 reduction reaction, and so on [52–60]. For example, B–doped C2N exhibits excellent performance for visible light driven CO reduction with a small limiting potential of –0.23 V [58]. Ji et al. found that the B atom supported on C2N might exhibit outstanding N2 reduction reaction activities with a low limiting potential of –0.15 V [59]. In particular, Yin et al. pointed out that sp2–hybridized B is optimal for N2 reduction and has outstanding capability in inhibiting competing hydrogen evolution reaction [60]. Inspired by the above studies, the potential of B–doped C2N as the NBRR photocatalyst was explored through DFT calculations. The results demonstrate that sp2–hybridized B doped C2N at N site (BN–C2N) exhibits excellent catalytic activity for Ph–NO2 conversion to Ph–NH2 with a low limiting potential of –0.30 V. The present work may provide a clear direction for discovering efficient metal−free NBRR catalysts. 2 Computational methods and models All DFT computations were implemented by using the Dmol3 code [61,62]. The Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange–correlation functional within a generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was adopted [63]. Grimme's method (DFT + D2) was used to describe the Van der Walls (vdW) interaction between NBRR intermediates and catalysts [64]. A conductor–like screening model (COSMO) was employed to simulate the water solvent environment in the whole process, and the dielectric constant of H2O solvent was set as 78.54 [65]. A 3 × 3 × 1 k–points in the Brillouin zone was used for the geometry optimization. The Bader charge was obtained by the PBE functional in Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [66,67]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structures and stabilities The possible B–doping sites of C2N, denoted as BC, BN, and Bint, are shown in Fig. 1 a. After structural optimization, all atoms in B–doped C2N are exactly on the same plane (Figure S1). The distance between B and its nearest C or N atom of BC, BN and Bint–C2N are 1.39, 1.43, and 1.49 Å, respectively, which are consistent with the previously reported values [59]. The stabilities of B–doped C2N were explored by studying cohesive energy (E c) and formation energy (E f) (Table S1). The results show that the E c of B–doped C2N around –6.70 eV, implying excellent thermodynamic stability. The small E f (0.30 ∼ 1.35 eV) of B–doped C2N indicate that the B dopant can be easily incorporated into C2N, which are in well agreement with previous studies [59]. In order to understand the electronic distribution and the chemical bonding, the electron localization function (ELF) was computed and the results are shown in Fig. 1b and S2. The electron density between B and N atoms in the three B–doped C2N both are 0.9, indicating that the significant B–N covalent bonds in BC, BN and Bint–C2N. Taking BN–C2N as an example, its thermal stability was evaluated by performing AIMD simulations at 500 K for a total period of 10 ps with the time step of 1.0 fs [68]. The structural snapshot and energy variations of BN–C2N against time are shown in Figure S3. The results imply that BN–C2N retains 2D lattice structure at the temperature of 500 K, confirming the thermodynamic stability of BN–C2N. 3.2 Electronic and optical properties It is well known that the electronic and optical properties of photocatalyst play an important role for catalytic performance in NBRR. The computed partial density of states (PDOSs) in Figure S4 show that the B atom in BC, BN and Bint–C2N belongs to sp2–, sp2–, and sp3–hybridized, respectively. For BC and BN, the B atom displays an occupied pz orbital and an unoccupied sp2 orbital. Two sp2 hybridization orbitals of single B atom interact with p orbitals of adjacent C or N atoms to form C–B or N−B chemical bonds. In the case of Bint−C2N, the B atom shows a sp3 hybridization feature, which connects with two–fold coordinated N atoms and displays one filled and one vacant sp3 orbital. The band structures of pristine and B–doped C2N were calculated and are shown in Figure S5. The calculated band gap of C2N (1.81 eV) is similar to previously work (1.77 eV) [59]. The BC, BN, and Bint–C2N are all semiconductors with band gaps of 1.40, 1.59, and 0.76 eV, respectively, which are decreased by doping B atom comparing to C2N. The unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) and the highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMOs) of pristine and B–doped C2N are shown in Fig. 2 . For pristine C2N, the LUMO localizes on all N atoms, and the HOMO mainly distributes on C atoms, indicating that the excited e −/h + is located on adjacent C and N atoms, which can easily recombine resulting in weak photocatalytic efficiency of pristine C2N. After doping with B atoms, the LUMO is mainly contributed by C and N atoms away from B atom, while the HOMO is mainly dominated by B atom and C and N atoms around B atom, thus we expect that B–doped C2N has better ability to separate the photogenerated e −/h +. Furthermore, the optical absorption curves of pristine and B–doped C2N are plotted in Figure S6. For C2N, the wavelength of optical absorption edge (λedge) is near 725 nm. Compared to C2N, the λedge of three B–doped C2N red–shift by 175, 75, 975 nm. Moreover, the absorption curve area of three B–doped C2N are larger than that of C2N. The above results show that B–doped C2N can expend the visible–light response range and generate more electrons upon the visible light irradiation. 3.3 Adsorption of Ph–NO2 molecule The first and key step for NBRR is the adsorption and activation of Ph–NO2 molecule on catalyst [68], which influences or determines the catalytic selectivity during the heterogeneous catalysis. Thus, the Ph−NO2 adsorption on BC, BN, and Bint–C2N were first examined. The adsorption energies (E ads) of Ph–NO2 on BC, BN, and Bint−C2N were calculated by considering all possible adsorption configurations, and the obtained stable structures are shown in Fig. 3 . It should be mentioned that the stable adsorption of Ph−NO2 on catalytic site is essential for the subsequent hydrogenation reaction. For BC−C2N, the Ph−NO2 molecule is weakly adsorbed with the small E ads (–0.51 eV) and large distance between Ph–NO2 and BC–C2N (3.00 Å). Bader charge analysis and charge difference density show that there is no charge transfer between Ph–NO2 and BC–C2N. The results clearly demonstrate that BC–C2N is not appropriate for NBRR photocatalyst. In contrast, the stable adsorption structures can be obtained for Ph–NO2 on BN and Bint–C2N, and the corresponding E ads are –2.41 and –3.01 eV, respectively. The Gibbs free energy (ΔG) for Ph–NO2 adsorption on BN and Bint–C2N are −1.63 and −2.26 eV, respectively, which is a spontaneous process. The formed B–N bond lengths are 1.45 and 1.39 Å, respectively, suggesting the strong chemisorption of Ph–NO2 with BN and Bint–C2N. Importantly, according to Bader charge analysis (Table S1), the O atom of Ph−NO2 attached to the substrate accepts about 0.30 and 0.45 |e|, thus resulting in the significant accumulation of negative charges around the O atom (yellow bubbles in Fig. 3b, c). To deeply understand the interaction of Ph–NO2 on BN and Bint–C2N, we calculated the PDOSs of Ph–NO2 adsorption which are shown in Fig. 4 . Before Ph–NO2 adsorption, the pz orbitals of B atom are well matched with π* orbital of Ph–NO2, which facilitates the adsorption and activation of Ph–NO2. After Ph–NO2 adsorption, there is an obvious hybridization between the O–2p and B–2p orbitals, demonstrating that the electron transfer occurs between B atom and Ph–NO2. Compared with the O–2p orbital of the free Ph–NO2 molecule, the σ occupied orbital of the adsorbed Ph–NO2 is far away from the Fermi level, resulting in stronger bonding strength between Ph–NO2 and B atom. Above the Fermi level, the empty π* orbitals move towards the Fermi level after Ph–NO2 adsorption, suggesting that the B atom donates the electrons to the π* orbitals of Ph–NO2. B–doped C2N adsorbs and activates Ph–NO2 via similar interaction mechanism of N2 adsorption, i.e., “acceptance–donation” process. Specifically, the antibonding bond of Ph–NO2 molecule accepting the electrons from B dopant is remarkable, which results in O atom with more negative charge. 3.4 Nitrobenzene reduction reactions In order to evaluate the catalytic performance of B–doped C2N for NBRR, BN–C2N was chosen as a representative to investigate the whole electroreduction pathways. All the possible reaction pathways of NBRR are displayed in Scheme 1. The optimized intermediates along the most favorable reaction path are shown in Fig. 5 , and the free energy profiles are summarized in Fig. 6 and S7. The Ph–NO2* can be hydrogenated to form Ph–NOOH* on the B site of BN–C2N with ΔG of 0.30 eV (Fig. 6), in which the H atom bounds with the O atom. Subsequently, Ph–NOOH* is further hydrogenated to form either Ph–NO* + H2O or Ph–N(OH)2*. The reaction of Ph–NOOH* → Ph–NO* + H2O is exothermic with ΔG of –1.77 eV, which is more energetically favorable than that of Ph–N(OH)2* formation (0.29 eV). After the H2O molecule is released, the remaining Ph–NO* will be hydrogenated to Ph–HNO* or Ph–NOH*. The calculated Gibbs free energy for Ph–NO* → Ph–HNO* decreases by 0.99 eV, which is lower than that of Ph–NOH* (ΔG = –0.68 eV). Ph–HNO* can be further hydrogenated to form Ph–HNOH*, and the corresponding ΔG value is 0 eV. The next two–step hydrogenation reactions are Ph–HNOH* → Ph–NH* + H2O → Ph–NH2* with ΔG of –2.62 and –0.66 eV, respectively. The released energy (7.37 eV) in above–mentioned hydrogenation steps is sufficient to overcome the required energy to release Ph–NH2 (3.17 eV), thus Ph–NH2* desorption is not a problematic obstacle. Besides, changing the pH of surrounding solvent can also promote Ph–NH2* desorption [15, 69]. According to the above discussion, the most energetically favorable pathway for NBRR on BN–C2N is identified as Ph–NO2 + *→ Ph–NO2* → Ph–NOOH* → Ph–NO* → Ph–HNO* → Ph–HNOH* → Ph–NH* → Ph–NH2* → Ph–NH2 + * path, in which the process of Ph–NO2* → Ph–NOOH* is the potential–determining step (PDS) with the ΔG max of 0.30 eV, indicating that BN–C2N exhibits excellent catalytic performance towards nitrobenzene conversion to aniline. Finally, we also investigated the catalytic activity of Bint–C2N for the NBRR. As shown in Figure S7, the Ph–NH* → Ph–NH2* is the PDS of NBRR on Bint–C2N with the limiting potential of –1.34 V, which is much larger than that of on BN–C2N (–0.30 V). 3.5 Electronic structure analysis To further explore the origin of the different catalytic activities of NBRR on BN–C2N and Bint–C2N, we investigated the electronic structures of BN–C2N and Bint–C2N with the Ph–NOOH* and Ph–NH* adsorption by examining PDOSs as shown in Fig. 7 . It is found that the interactions between the catalyst and the Ph–NOOH intermediate mainly come from the B–2p and O–2p orbitals. For BN–C2N, the O−2p orbitals show an orbital overlap with the B–2p orbitals in the energy range from −6.30 eV to −2.10 eV (Fig. 7a). Compared with BN–C2N, B–2p orbitals of the Bint–C2N exhibit stronger orbital overlap with O–2p orbitals of Ph–NOOH* as its larger energy range from −9.80 eV to −1.00 eV (Fig. 7b). Similarly, Bint–C2N has stronger hybridization with the Ph–NH* (−9.10 ∼ −2.80 eV) than that of BN–C2N (−8.20 ∼ −2.80 eV), indicating that there is a coupling effect between the two steps, i.e., the stronger Ph–NOOH* adsorption is always followed by the stronger Ph–NH* adsorption. Apparently, the compromise has to be made to achieve the optimal ΔG value. For Bint–C2N, the interaction with Ph–NH* is too strong to form Ph–NH2* (ΔG= 1.34 eV) as the excessive adsorption of Ph–NH* on the catalytic site will form dead–end species, thus blocking the catalytic sites at the relevant potential. Overall, BN–C2N is the most promising NBRR catalyst, which has only 0.30 eV and –0.66 eV free energy changes in the two key hydrogenation steps. 3.6 Hydrogen evolution reaction on BN–C2N When the NBRR process occurs in aqueous solution, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) should be considered because it will compete with NBRR. First, in order to evaluate the HER performance of BN–C2N, four possible active sites were investigated, which are labeled as N1, N2, N3, and B in Figure S8a. According to the Gibbs energy profile summarized in Figure S8a, it can be found that H atom prefers to adsorb at the N3 site (ΔG = −0.64 eV) rather than the B site (ΔG = −0.30 eV). NBRR (B site) and HER (N3 site) are performed at different sites of BN–C2N, indicating that the B active sites will bind to Ph–NO2 and not be covered by H atom. Thus, BN−C2N exhibits superior selectivity for NBRR. 4 Conclusions In summary, we systematically investigated the catalytic performance of B–doped C2N for NBRR by means of DFT computations. Our results indicate that the sp2–hybridized B doped C2N is an excellent electrocatalyst for aniline production, and the corresponding optimal path is Ph–NO2 + * → Ph–NO2* → Ph–NOOH* → Ph–NO* → Ph–HNO* → Ph–HNOH* → Ph–NH* → Ph–NH2* → Ph–NH2 + *, in which the Ph–NO2* hydrogenation is the potential–determining step with a low limiting potential of –0.30 V. The NBRR photocatalytic activity of B–doped C2N is dependent on their binding strength with Ph–NOOH* and Ph–NH*, which can be deeply understood on the basis of the electronic structure analyses. Thus, these computations may open up a new avenue to design high–efficiency metal–free photocatalysts for NBRR. coredata.dc:description: Developing low–cost and efficient materials for nitrobenzene reduction reaction (NBRR) is attractive and challengeable. Great research efforts have been made in metal–based materials, while the metal–free catalysts for nitrobenzene (Ph–NO2) conversion have been rarely explored. Herein, by means of density functional theory (DFT) calculations, the potential of B–doped C2N as metal–free photocatalyst for NBRR was systematically investigated. The results reveal that the sp2–hybridized B doped C2N at N site (BN–C2N) exhibits high catalytic activity for nitrobenzene conversion to aniline (Ph–NH2) with a low limiting potential of –0.30 V. Besides, BN–C2N can improve the photoconversion efficiency by broadening the light absorption of C2N. Therefore, BN–C2N is a promising metal–free photocatalyst for NBRR, which may open a new avenue for Ph–NO2 conversion under ambient conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Metal–free C2N doped with sp2–hybridized B atom as high–efficiency photocatalyst for nitrobenzene reduction reaction: A density functional theory study
